title: Mushrooms (PDQ®)
description: Medicinal mushrooms have been used as an addition to standard cancer treatments in Asia. Mushrooms are being studied to find out how they affect the immune system and if they have anticancer effects. Get detailed information about the use of medicinal mushrooms for cancer in this clinician summary.
cleaned_text: Medicinal Mushrooms (PDQ®)-Health Professional Version Introduction Medicinal mushrooms have been used for hundreds of years, mainly in Asian countries, for treatment of [infections](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45364&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov). More recently, they have also been used in the treatment of [pulmonary diseases](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=748821&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) and [cancer](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45333&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov). Medicinal mushrooms have been approved [adjuncts](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=367454&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) to standard cancer treatments in Japan and China for more than 30 years and have an extensive [clinical](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44168&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) history of safe use as single agents or combined with [radiation](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45072&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) therapy or [chemotherapy](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45214&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov). More than 100 species of medicinal mushrooms are used in Asia. Some of the more commonly used species include the following: - Ganoderma lucidum (reishi). frondosa (maitake). effects of mushrooms on [immune response](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45722&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) pathways and on direct [antitumor](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=446109&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) mechanisms. The immune effects are mediated through the mushroom's stimulation of innate [immune cells](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46356&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov), such as [monocytes](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46282&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov), [natural killer cells](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44062&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov), and [dendritic cells](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44948&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov). The activity is generally considered to be caused by the presence of high- [molecular-weight](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=740563&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) [polysaccharides](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44162&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) (beta-glucans) in the mushrooms, although other constituents may also be involved. [Clinical trials](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45961&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) in cancer patients have demonstrated that G. lucidum products are generally well tolerated.[ [1](#cit/section_1.1)] Several companies distribute medicinal mushrooms as [dietary supplements](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=373932&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov). In the United States, dietary supplements are regulated as foods, not [drugs](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=348921&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov). Therefore, premarket evaluation and approval of such supplements by the [U.S. Food and Drug Administration](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=454785&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) (FDA) are not required unless specific disease [prevention](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=439419&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) or treatment claims are made. Because dietary supplements are not formally reviewed for manufacturing consistency, ingredients may vary considerably from lot to lot and there is no guarantee that ingredients claimed on product labels are present (or are present in the specified amounts). The FDA has not approved the use of medicinal mushrooms as a treatment for cancer or any other medical [condition](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=651193&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov). [[PUBMED Abstract]](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&db=PubMed&list_uids=22696372&dopt=Abstract) Turkey Tail and Polysaccharide-K General Information Turkey tail is a woody bracket polypore [fungus](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44571&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) that grows on dead logs worldwide. The scientific name of turkey tail is Trametes versicolor (L.) Lloyd, although it has been known by other names, notably Coriolus versicolor (L. ex Fr.) Quel. It is known as Yun Zhi in [traditional Chinese medicine](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=449722&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) and Kawaratake (roof tile fungus) in Japan. The name turkey tail refers to its concentric rings of brown and tan, which resemble the tail feathers of a turkey. There are many other species of Trametes, some of which are difficult to distinguish from turkey tail. Internal transcribed spacer sequences alone have been found inadequate to distinguish turkey tail from other species of Trametes, so additional molecular characters are required for that task.[ [1](#cit/section_2.1)] Another Trametes species used primarily in China is Trametes robiniophila Murr, also known as Huaier. History The fungus has been used in traditional Chinese medicine for many years to treat [pulmonary diseases](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=748821&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov).[ [2](#cit/section_2.2), [3](#cit/section_2.3)] A purified hot water [extract](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=407760&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) prepared from the cultivated fungal mycelium has been used in Japan for its [immunomodulatory](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=367426&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) effects as an adjuvant treatment for [cancer](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45333&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov).[ [4](#cit/section_2.4)- [6](#cit/section_2.6)] [Polysaccharide](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44162&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov)-K (PSK) or krestin, from the mushroom T. versicolor, is an approved mushroom product used for cancer treatment in Japan. PSK is a proprietary formulation from the Kureha Corporation. PSK has been used as an adjunctive cancer treatment in thousands of patients since the mid-1970s. The safety record for PSK is well established in Japan. Few [adverse events](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=444960&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) have been reported in patients treated with PSK. Polysaccharopeptide (PSP) is another [extract](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=407760&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) from T. versicolor produced in China. Laboratory/Animal/Preclinical Studies Chemistry The best known constituent of turkey tail is the [glycoprotein](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44034&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) mixture known as PSK. PSK is not a homogeneous substance, with a range of [molecular weights](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=740563&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) averaging 9.4 kDa (range 5-300 kDa). The composed main chain [beta-(1,4) glucan](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44147&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) with beta-(1,3)- and beta-(1,6)-linked side chains. Small amounts of galactose, mannose, and arabinose have also been detected in the hydrolysate. Between 25% and 38% of the mass comes from a covalently linked [protein](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46092&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) [amino acid](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=446104&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) PSK [radiolabeled](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45857&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) with C-14 has been used to study the [oral](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44068&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) [bioavailability](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44225&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) and distribution of PSK in mice, rats, and rabbits. A fraction of the [dose](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44664&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) appears to be orally absorbed, more or less intact, and is excreted in [bile](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46508&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) over several hours. However, most of the radiolabeled dose is found in exhaled air, suggesting that the [digestion](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=463707&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) of PSK may occur in the gut or the [metabolism](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46173&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) of absorbed PSK may occur somewhere else in the body.[ [7](#cit/section_2.7)] A [monoclonal antibody](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46066&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) (specific for PSK) that neutralizes PSK's [antitumor](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=446109&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) effects has been developed. It has been used to validate the presence of PSK in [implanted](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=285636&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) [tumors](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46634&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov).[ [8](#cit/section_2.8)] PSP, a very similar substance, has also been purified from a different strain of turkey tail; PSP and PSK differ somewhat in sugar composition.[ [2](#cit/section_2.2)] A [lipid](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46068&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) component of PSK has been separated by lipase treatment and found to have toll-like [receptor](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44958&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) 2 [agonist](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46054&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) activity, [synergistic](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=330184&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) with the protein-bound [beta-glucan](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44147&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov). The lipid component was primarily linoleic [acid](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=642987&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov), with [ have also been isolated from [cultures](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=476357&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) of T. versicolor. Mechanistic studies Since the earliest reports of [clinical](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44168&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) benefits, other [investigators](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44685&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) have sought to define the mechanism of PSK's beneficial action. One group hypothesized that [T-cell](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44928&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) [dysfunction](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=390268&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov), including [apoptosis](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46524&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) of [peripheral blood](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46011&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) T cells, commonly occurs in patients receiving [chemotherapy](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45214&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov).[ [12](#cit/section_2.12)] They postulated that reversal of T-cell dysfunction induced by chemotherapy could reduce the [adverse effects](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44922&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) or enhance the antitumor effect. PSK is reported to enhance [natural killer (NK) and T-cell activities by patients with curatively [resected](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45868&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) [stage III gastric cancer](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45904&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) were randomly with the second-generation dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase-inhibitory oral (n = 10) or S-1 plus PSK (n = 10). At 5 weeks after adjuvant therapy, T-cell apoptosis was significantly higher in the S-1-alone group than in the S-1-plus-PSK group, leading the authors to conclude that PSK could partially prevent the T-cell apoptosis induced by S-1. Another group of investigators studied the effect of PSK added to [tegafur/uracil](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=530325&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) (UFT) chemotherapy compared with that of UFT alone.[ [13](#cit/section_2.13)] [Baseline](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=467830&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) immune parameters were comparable in the two groups. However, CD57-positive T cells decreased more significantly after [surgery](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45570&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) for patients treated with PSK than for those in the [control group](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44149&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) (P = .0486). These investigators had previously noted that a high CD57-positive cell count was an indicator of poor [prognosis](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45849&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) in patients with advanced [gastric cancer](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=454513&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov), leading them to suggest that PSK may improve [overall survival](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=655245&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) (OS) partly by inhibiting CD57-positive T cells. Noting that hosts become [immunocompromised](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45723&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) at the time of [tumor progression](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45669&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) and that decreased expression of major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I by the tumor is one mechanism that allows it to evade destruction by [cytotoxic T](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45664&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) [lymphocytes](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45765&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov), investigators conducted a [retrospective study](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44956&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) to evaluate the expression of MHC class I by immunohistochemical staining in the [primary lesions](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45847&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) of patients with [stage II](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46037&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) or stage III gastric cancer.[ [14](#cit/section_2.14)] They analyzed data from 349 patients who had undergone adjuvant therapy (after [curative](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=318813&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) [resection](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46565&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov)) between 1995 and 2008; 225 patients received [adjuvant chemotherapy](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45587&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) with an oral fluoropyrimidine alone, while 124 patients received adjuvant chemotherapy plus PSK 3 [g](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=373014&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov)/d. Although this was not a [randomized trial](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45858&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov), baseline characteristics of the patients were well matched. The [mean](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=285973&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) duration of [follow-up](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44671&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) was 49 months. Three-year [recurrence](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45861&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov)-free survival (RFS) rates were the same for both groups (60% for the PSK group and 62% for the chemotherapy-only group). For MHC expression-negative cases, the 3-year RFS rates were 65% for the PSK group and 50% for the chemotherapy-only group; the difference was not considered [significant](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=390271&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov). For 82 MHC expression-negative patients with [lymph node](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45762&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) status of pN2 or greater, the RFS rates were 65% for the PSK group and 34% for the chemotherapy-only group—a significant difference with no P value offered. The authors concluded that PSK adjuvant [immunotherapy](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45729&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) may be effective in MHC class I-negative patients with advanced lymph node [metastasis](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46710&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) of pN2 or greater. While the mechanism of action for PSK in general and in [colorectal cancer](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=444983&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) specifically is not clearly defined, the potential activity of PSK as an immunomodulatory adjunct to [chemoradiation](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=306495&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) therapy in [rectal cancer](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=529764&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) has been studied.[ [15](#cit/section_2.15)] Thirty patients with stage II or III rectal cancer who were treated with S-1 and [external-beam radiation therapy](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46751&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) were randomly assigned to receive either the standard [regimen](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45864&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) or standard regimen plus PSK. A number of cellular and humoral immune parameters were tested. An increase in peripheral [blood](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=270735&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) NK cells after therapy was observed in the PSK-treated group compared with the control group. [Immunosuppressive](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44041&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) acidic protein (IAP) levels have been reported to be elevated in cancer patients and correlated to cancer [progression](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44078&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) and prognosis. In the study, a more-marked decrease in IAP level was observed in patients treated with PSK than in those treated in the control group. In addition, [cytotoxic T cells](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45664&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) increased in the peritumoral [mucosa](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=257213&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) and normal mucosa within the radiation field in the PSK-treated group. The authors of the study concluded that PSK treatment may promote local [tissue](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46683&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) [immunity](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=468803&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) within the radiation field. One review included [preclinical studies](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44517&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) conducted in [lung cancer](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=445043&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) models using either PSK or other T. versicolor preparations.[ [16](#cit/section_2.16)] Data from the 15 preclinical studies supported the anticancer effects of PSK by way of immunomodulation and [potentiation](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=330176&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) of immune surveillance. In [animal models](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=43996&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov), direct antitumor effects resulted in reduced tumor growth and metastases. Human Studies Gastric cancer Observational studies Gastric cancer is the most common [malignancy](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45771&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) [diagnosed](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46450&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) in Korea. Investigators in Korea performed a retrospective [analysis](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=390238&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) of survival in patients who received PSK in addition to chemotherapy and in those who received chemotherapy only (control group).[ [17](#cit/section_2.17)] Unfortunately, the chemotherapy regimens differed in that the PSK patients were treated with [fluorouracil](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=635764&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) and [mitomycin-C](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=713798&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) (207 patients), while the controls received fluorouracil with [doxorubicin](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=560140&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov)-based chemotherapy (103 patients), introducing a potential [bias](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44646&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) in the interpretation of the results. Patients with all stages of gastric cancer were included in the analysis. Overall, there was no difference between groups in 5-year [disease-free survival](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44023&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) (DFS) or [progression-free survival](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44782&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) (PFS) subgroup analysis, PSK recipients with stage IB or stage II disease showed superior 5-year survival (84.4% vs. 67.6%; P = .019), but no significant benefit was observed in patients with higher-stage disease. Another retrospective analysis of nonrandomized data evaluated 254 patients with gastric [carcinoma](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45963&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) undergoing [curative surgery](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=688838&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) with [postoperative](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=43980&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) adjuvant treatment in Japan.[ [18](#cit/section_2.18)] Researchers compared 139 patients who received chemotherapy alone with 115 patients who received chemotherapy plus PSK. There were no significant differences between groups in patient demographics or tumor characteristics at baseline. There were no differences between groups in 5-year RFS rates (52.7% in the PSK group and 52.7% in the control group) or 5-year OS rates (57.1% in the PSK group and 58.3% in the control group). In a [subset analysis](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=285981&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) of patients with more than seven involved [lymph nodes](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45762&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) (pN3), the 5-year OS rate was significantly higher in the PSK group (47.8%) than that in the control group (22.8%; P = .0317). Hence, these results contradict the findings from the Korean analysis. Clinical trials A study published in 1994 first suggested the clinical benefit of adjuvant PSK for patients who underwent curative resection of gastric cancer in Japan.[ [19](#cit/section_2.19)] Investigators randomly assigned 262 patients who had undergone curative [gastrectomy](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46397&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) to receive either [standard treatment](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44930&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) with [intravenous](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46682&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) mitomycin and oral fluorouracil, or chemotherapy plus protein-bound PSK. Patients were [monitored](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=454803&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) for 5 to 7 years. PSK improved both the 5-year DFS rate rate](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44301&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) (73.0% vs. 60.0%; P = .044), compared with the standard treatment group. Treatment with PSK was well tolerated, with good [compliance](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=446112&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov). The authors concluded that PSK should be added to standard chemotherapy for gastric cancer patients who undergo curative gastrectomy. A 2007 [meta-analysis](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=691484&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) included 8,009 patients from eight [randomized](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45858&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) [controlled trials](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44014&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) (RCTs) of adjuvant of gastric cancers:[ [20](#cit/section_2.20)] 4,037 patients received PSK with chemotherapy, and 3,972 patients received the same chemotherapy alone. The OS [hazard ratio](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=618612&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) was 0.88 (95% confidence interval [CI], 0.79-0.98; P = .018), indicating improved survival with the addition of PSK, with no significant heterogeneity between the treatment effects observed in the different studies. The three trials with the best quality supported the findings from the eight studies. The authors concluded that PSK was effective as adjuvant immunotherapy for patients with gastric cancer and suggested that this improvement may well be both statistically and clinically significant. One other large study not included in this meta-analysis was a Japanese multicenter comparative trial of adjuvant chemotherapy versus adjuvant chemotherapy and PSK involving 751 patients undergoing curative resection, conducted from 1978 to 1981.[ [21](#cit/section_2.21)] Patients were randomly assigned to receive either chemotherapy with mitomycin-C plus oral [tegafur](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45201&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) (also known as futraful) with (n = 377) or without (n = 374) PSK 3 g/d. To qualify for a level of evidence [analysis](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=390238&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov), a study must: - Be published in a [peer-reviewed scientific journal](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=537399&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov). - Report on a [therapeutic](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=43985&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) [outcome](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=467853&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov)or outcomes, such as [tumor](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46634&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) [response](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44085&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov), improvement in survival, or measured improvement in [quality of life](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45417&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov). - Describe [clinical](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44168&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov)findings in sufficient detail that a meaningful evaluation can be made. Separate levels of evidence scores are assigned to qualifying human studies on the basis of statistical strength of the study design and [scientific](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44724&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov) strength of the treatment outcomes (i.e., [endpoints](/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=346519&version=healthprofessional&language=English&dictionary=Cancer.gov)) measured. The resulting two scores are then combined to produce an overall score. For an explanation of the scores and additional information about levels of evidence analysis of integrative, alternative, and complementary therapies for cancer, see [Levels of Evidence for Human Studies of Integrative, Alternative, and Complementary Therapies](/publications/pdq/levels-evidence/cam).
